Welcome to the 'Grid'

Today i am going to look at 2 different types of grid based solutions, and present my findings.

What is a grid system? The fundamentals of the grid layout is for a consistent design approach, making sure all of the elements are equally aligned.

960px width 12 column width with 20px gutters

  • The 960 grid system (created by Nathan Smith) has been around for a few years now.

1140px width 12 column width with 40px gutters

  • 1140px (created by Australian Andy Taylor) take a mobile first approach with a responsive framework.

960px

Prototype 1 : 960 grid Prototype

Pro's:

  • It allows white space either side of the content.
  • It divides nicely into a wide range of columns ( 2,3,4,5,6 and 8 ) with all relevant combinations.
  • Works well on small screens.
  • Support all modern browsers.

Cons:

  • Content width is limited to 940px

1140px

Prototype 2 : 1140 grid Prototype

Pro's

  • Main content area 745px
  • Fits perfectly on 1280px monitor, on smaller monitors and modern browsers (IE9+) the framework shrinks and matches the screens view-port. (responsive approach)
  • white space between regions

Con's

  • Doesn't work on IE6, content stretches to full width
  • No responsive layout on IE6/7/8, can cause issues for users with small monitors.

Conclusions & Findings*Warning - Apologies if you have found i move out of scope looking at responsive design.. Originally i wanted to just focus on the grid framework but I've found that the two are closely linked.

Overall i have found there is a time and place to use a particular grid framework, however 'there’s is definitely not a one fits all solution'.

A major factor to consider when making a decision on which to use is the ‘target audience’.

E.g. An older user might not necessarily have the most up-to date technology and still stuck with an old CRT monitor. - 960px grid solution would be more appropriate.

I also found that white space is also very important in a browsing experience, “The larger the screen, the greater the optimum comfortable viewing distance.”

This link below is an example of that - may hurt eyes if your using a widescreen monitor.E.g. http://d3pr5r64n04s3o.cloudfront.net/articles/085_wide/demo-scale/index.html
